questions.text: Which of the following is true about coagulative necrosis?

choices.text: It is the least common type of necrosis
Brain is most likely to undergo coagulative necrosis
It causes a wedge-shaped necrosis in the affected organs

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) It causes a wedge-shaped necrosis in the affected organs

 

Explanation:

Coagulative Necrosis causes a wedge-shaped necrosis in the affected organs.

  • Most common type of necrosis. (Option A ruled out)
  • Seen in solid organs like the kidney, liver, and heart (Option B ruled out).
    • Brain and Pancreas show liquefactive necrosis
  • Grossly, wedge-shaped necrosis is seen.
  • Usually seen following an infarct (when blood supply is hampered)
  • Tissue architecture is preserved. (Option D ruled out)
  • Microscopically, ghost cells are seen.
    • These show preserved outlines but details are lost.

questions.text: A 65 year male presents with weakness on the right half of his body. He is a known case of atrial fibrillation, not on any treatment. CT angiography shows a complete occlusion of a small branch of the middle cerebral artery. What is the most likely change seen in this pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Liquefactive necrosis

 

Explanation: 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ischemic stroke due to thromboembolism - affected area of the brain shows liquefaction necrosis/colliquative necrosis.

Coagulative Necrosis (Option A) is seen in solid organs like the kidney, liver, and heart (Most common)

Fibrinoid Necrosis (Option D) is seen in cases where antigen-antibody complexes are formed (E.g., PAN, RHD, Malignant HTN and SLE)

Apoptosis (Option C) is a programmed cell death.

  • Physiological: Organogenesis or Embryogenesis.
  • Pathological: 2 bodies:
    • Councilman bodies seen with Hepatitis-C Virus
    • Colloid bodies or Civatte bodies seen in Lichen planus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a persistent cough, weight loss, and night sweats. A chest X-ray shows cavitary lesions in the upper lobes of the lungs. Sputum analysis is positive for acid-fast bacilli. A biopsy is taken, and a cut section of the lung is shown below.What type of necrosis is most likely present in this patient's lung tissue?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Caseous necrosis

Explanation:

This is a case of Pulmonary tuberculosis which presents with Caseous Necrosis in the lungs.

  • Caseous necrosis is characterized by a cheese-like appearance of affected tissues (Option B)
  • Results from the combination of coagulative necrosis (most common form of necrosis) and liquefactive necrosis.
  • It is associated with high lipid content in the cell walls 
  • Commonly seen in conditions (high lipid content) such as
    • Tuberculosis (caseating granuloma with mycolic acid deposition), 
    • Fungal infections (histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis),
    • Syphilis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not involve fibrinoid necrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Atherosclerosis

Explanation:
Atherosclerosis (cholesterol or fat deposition in blood vessels) is not involved in Fibrinoid Necrosis.

  • It is associated with antibody-antigen complex—---> immune complex deposition in vessel walls—---> a fibrin-like appearance in vessel walls.
  • It's seen in type I or III hypersensitivity reactions. 
  • Observed in conditions like,
    • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)
    • Rheumatic heart disease (with Aschoff bodies), 
    • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and
    • Malignant hypertension.

questions.text:
Based on the provided image, which features are indicative of the type of gangrene depicted?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Presence of gas bubbles in the affected tissue
Formation of bullae filled with fluid
Dry, shrunken, and mummified appearance with a clear demarcation
Presence of foul-smelling discharge and crepitus on palpation

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Dry, shrunken, and mummified appearance with a clear demarcation

Explanation:

The image shows dry gangrene, characterized by a dry, shrunken, mummified appearance with a well-defined line of demarcation.

Difference between dry gangrene and wet gangrene: 

 

Dry gangrene

Wet gangrene

Site 

Commonly limbs 

More common in the bowel

Mechanism

Arterial occlusion

More commonly, venous obstruction

Pathology

Coagulative necrosis

Liquefactive necrosis

Macroscopy

Organ dry, shrunken, and black

Part is moist, soft, swollen, rotten, and dark

Line of demarcation

Present - at the junction between healthy and gangrenous part

No clear-cut line of demarcation

Infection 

No infection, therefore no pus or any fluid

Infection present, with pus formation. (Option B ruled out)

Prognosis

Generally better due to little septicemia.

Generally poor due to profound toxaemia.

 

Presence of gas bubbles in the affected tissue (Option A) and Presence of foul-smelling discharge and crepitus on palpation (Option B) describe features more characteristic of gas gangrene because of development of gas or bacterial formation leading to formation of gas bubbles.

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair among the following
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Fat necrosis- Pancreatic lipase- Omentum

Explanation:

Among the given options, the correctly represented pathology is fat necrosis caused by pancreatic lipases in the breast. In cases of acute pancreatitis, lipase is released from the pancreas which goes to omentum and breaks fat there causing fat necrosis.

 

Type of necrosis

Pathology

Conditions

Coagulative 

Lysosomal enzymes derived from

infiltrating leukocytes

Ischemia in all organs except the brain

Liquefactive

Microbes stimulating leukocyte enzymes

Bacterial and fungal infections

Ischemia in brain

Caseous

Formation of granuloma by lymphocytes and activated macrophages (giant cells, epithelioid cells).

Tuberculosis,Fungal infections( Histoplasmosis, Coccidioidomycosis) ,Syphilis

Gangrenous

Ischemia and necrosis 

Lower and upper limb

Fat necrosis

Pancreatic enzymes leak out of

damaged acinar cells

Pancreatitis, traumatic fat necrosis of the breast. 

Fibrinoid 

Immune reactions involving blood vessels

Polyarteritis nodosa, SLE, Arthus reaction, rheumatic heart disease, malignant hypertension, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about apoptosis is false?

choices.text: Characterized by the activation of caspases leading to DNA fragmentation.
Inflammatory response and release of damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs).
Chromatin condensation and formation of cytoplasmic blebs.
Eliminates cells that are injured beyond repair without eliciting a host reaction.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Inflammatory response and release of damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs).

 

Explanation:

Apoptosis is a non-inflammatory, programmed cell death process. It does not release DAMPs in a way that triggers a strong inflammatory response, unlike necrosis, which does cause inflammation and DAMP release.

Apoptosis (Caspase dependent programmed cell death):

  • It is an active process.
  • It eliminates cells that are injured beyond repair without eliciting a host reaction, thus limiting collateral tissue damage. (Option D ruled out) 
  • Apoptosis results from the activation of enzymes called caspases leading to DNA fragmentation. (Option A ruled out)
  • Hallmark of apoptosis: Nuclear chromatin condensation and formation of cytoplasmic blebs. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text:
Match the following apoptotic genes with their functions:

 


	
		
			
			1. BCL2 , MCL1
			
			
			a. Allows cytochrome c leakage
			
		
		
			
			2. BAX, BAK
			
			
			b. Initiates apoptosis when upregulated
			
		
		
			
			3. BAD, BID, NOXA
			
			
			c. Prevents  leakage of cytochrome C from the cytosol
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 1-c , 2-a , 3-b

Explanation:

  • Anti Apoptotic genes :- BCL-2 , BCL-XL , MCL-1
  • Pro Apoptotic genes:- BAX and BAK
  • Apoptosis initiators (Stress sensors):- BAD, BIM, BID, Noxa and Pum

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis in the correct order.

i. Binding of Fas ligand of T cells to Fas
ii. Trimerization of Fas
iii. Activation of caspase 8, 10.
iv. Formation of FADD
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) i>ii>iv>iii

Explanation:

  • Apoptosis occurs in two steps: Initiation and execution.
  • The initiation phase contains extrinsic and intrinsic pathways.

The extrinsic pathway of apoptosis starts outside the cells in the following order:

 

  1. Presence of Fas/CD95 on the outer part of the cell membrane
  2. Binding of Fas/CD95 ligand of T cells to Fas
  3. Trimerization of Fas
  4. Formation of FADD (Fas-associated death domain)
  5. Activation of caspase 8, 10 (by conversion of procaspase 8 and 10 to caspase 8 and 10)

In intrinsic pathway, caspase 9 is activated.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the apoptosome complex?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Cyt C and Apaf

Explanation:

The Apoptosome is a multi-protein complex that plays a critical role in the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway of apoptosis, formed when cytochrome C (Cyt C) is released from mitochondria into the cytosol in response to cellular stress or damage. Once in the cytosol:

  • Cytochrome c binds to Apaf-1 (apoptotic protease activating factor-1) in the presence of dATP/ATP

  • This triggers the formation of the apoptosome complex

  • The apoptosome then recruits and activates procaspase-9, which leads to activation of downstream executioner caspases (3, 6, 7)

  • Structurally, apoptosomes are comprising of wheel-like hexamer configuration.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is not a component of ‘eat-me signals’ of efferocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer. D) Fas Ligand

Explanation:

Fas ligand is a component of Apoptosis and not efferocytosis.

Efferocytosis:

  • The apoptotic bodies give the eat-me signals, which are expressed as C1q, Thrombospondin, and PS (Phosphatidyl Serine).
  • In the normal cell, the Phosphatidyl Serine is present in the inner leaflet, but in the apoptotic cell, it comes out.
    • This is known as Phosphatidyl Serine Flipping (Defective in Scott syndrome).
  • Based on this flipping, the Macrophage engulfs the apoptotic bodies, which is called Efferocytosis.

Fas ligand is not an eat-me signal; it is a component of the initiating pathway via which apoptosis starts.

Defect of flipping of  Phosphatidyl Serine: Scott syndrome: Affects apoptosis and platelet function.

Note: Cancer cells express CD47 to Macrophages. CD47 is a "Do not Eat me" signal.

questions.text: Which of the following cell deaths is most likely to show pattern B?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Apoptosis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pattern B shows discrete DNA bands at regular intervals.
  • This is characteristic of internucleosomal cleavage into fragments of ~180–200 base pairs.
  • Such a “DNA ladder” is a hallmark of apoptotic cell death.

 

DNA Fragmentation Patterns in Cell Death (Agarose Gel Electrophoresis)

Apoptosis:

  • Mechanism: Specific endonucleases cleave DNA at internucleosomal regions.
  • Gel Pattern: Produces a "DNA ladder" with regular 180–200 bp fragments.
  • Diagnostic Value: Presence of ladder indicates programmed cell death.
     

Necrosis:

  • Mechanism: Random, widespread DNA degradation due to cellular disintegration.
  • Gel Pattern: Appears as a diffuse smear without defined bands.
  • Diagnostic Value: Smear indicates uncontrolled or accidental cell death.
     

Apoptosis vs Necrosis on Agarose Gel:

Feature

Apoptosis (Option A) (Option D ruled out)

Necrosis (Options B & C ruled out)

DNA Cleavage

Internucleosomal, specific

Random and nonspecific

Enzyme Involved

Activated endonucleases

Non-specific degradation by cellular enzymes

Electrophoresis Result

Ladder pattern (discrete bands)

Smear pattern (continuous degradation)

Fragment Size

Multiples of ~180–200 base pairs

Heterogeneous, unorganized fragments

Interpretation

Indicates controlled cell death

Indicates uncontrolled cell death

questions.text: Which of the following are involved in the pathogenesis of pyroptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Caspase 1 and inflammasome 

Explanation:

Caspase 1 and the inflammasome are the entities responsible for a form of cell death known as Pyroptosis.

  • A form of apoptosis in which there is release of the fever-inducing cytokine IL-1.
  • Seen in response to bacterial infections like Salmonella and Shigella.
  • Microbial products entering infected cells are recognized by cytoplasmic receptors, activating the multiprotein complex inflammasome.
  • Inflammasome activates caspases 1, 4, 5, and 11. They will together result in the killing of the cell (apoptosis).
  • Caspase 1, which converts the inactive IL-1 to active IL-1, causing fever, inflammation and leucocyte recruitment 

 

Caspase 8 and FADD (Option A) are involved in the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis.

RIPK3 and MLKL (Option B) are involved in necroptosis. 

Iron and glutathione antioxidants (Option D) are involved in ferroptosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about programmed necrosis?

choices.text: It helps kill the Herpes simplex virus.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Caspase-independent programmed cell death.

Explanation:

Necroptosis is a caspase-independent programmed cell death.

  • Programmed necrosis is also known as Necroptosis.
  • It is a type of caspase-independent programmed cell death that presents with Inflammation. (Option B ruled out)
  • It has features of both necrosis and apoptosis.
  • It is both physiological and pathological (Option C ruled out)
  • It helps in killing Cytomegalovirus (CMV) and not HSV. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which type of cell death prevents metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Anoikis

Explanation:

Anoikis is a type of cell death which prevents metastasis.

  • A type of apoptosis in which the cell undergoes programmed cell death when cells detach from the surrounding extracellular matrix (ECM) or neighbouring cells. 
  • When cancer cells detach from the primary tumor, they are susceptible to anoikis. 
  • Acts as a barrier against the survival and dissemination of these detached cancer cells
  • Anoikis is a type of cell death which, if occurs, prevents spread of cancer or metastasis.
